qas.question: What did the technique in Gliezes' piece Le Depiquage represent?
Who painted the Wedding, show at Salon des Independants in 1912?
Which of Gliezes pieces was featured at Salon de la Section d'Or?
What did the technique in Gliezes' piece Le Depiquage not represent?
Who painted the Wedding, show at Salon des Independants in 1913?
Which of Gliezes pieces was not featured at Salon de la Section d'Or?

plausible_answers.text: Umberto Boccioni, Gino Severini and Carlo Carrà

qas.question: Who did not make a response in early cubism?
What did not give form to the notion of simultaneity?

context: This technique of representing simultaneity, multiple viewpoints (or <a0_0><b3_0>relative motion<b3_0/>)<a0_0/> is pushed to a high degree of complexity in Gleizes' monumental <a2_0><b5_0>Le Dépiquage des Moissons<b5_0/> (Harvest Threshing)<a2_0/>, exhibited at the 1912 Salon de la Section d'Or, Le Fauconnier’s Abundance shown at the Indépendants of 1911, and Delaunay's City of Paris, shown at the Indépendants in 1912. These ambitious works are some of the largest paintings in the history of Cubism. <a1_0><b4_0>Léger<a1_0/>’s<b4_0/> The Wedding, also shown at the <b7_0>Salon des Indépendants<b7_0/> in 1912, gave form to the notion of simultaneity by presenting different motifs as occurring within a single temporal frame, where responses to the past and present interpenetrate with collective force. The conjunction of such subject matter with simultaneity aligns Salon Cubism with early Futurist paintings by <b6_0>Umberto Boccioni, Gino Severini and Carlo Carrà<b6_0/>; themselves made in response to early Cubism.
